questions.text: Identify the crystal in a patient with urinary pH of 8.7: (INICET MAY 2024)

Ans. A) Triple Phosphate

questions.text: Enzyme deficient in pompe’s disease is: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Alpha 1, 4 glucosidase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand the enzymatic basis of Pompe's disease, recognizing that it is caused by a deficiency of alpha-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase). Be aware of the clinical manifestations and biochemical abnormalities associated with Pompe's disease, which is characterized by the accumulation of glycogen in various tissues, particularly in muscles.

questions.text: A baby assessed 5 minutes after birth is found to be pink, with blue extremities, and irregular respiration. Heart rate is 80 beats per minute. There is grimace and some flexion. What is the Apgar score for this baby? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Apgar score is used to quickly assess the overall health of a newborn, with a score of 5 indicating the need for some medical intervention but not immediate resuscitation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of some dehydration in a 5-year-old child? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lethargy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lethargy is a sign of severe dehydration, whereas delayed skin pinch and sunken eyeballs can be signs of both some and severe dehydration in a 5-year-old child.

questions.text: Banding technique used for dicentric chromosomes: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) C

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Dicentric chromosome is an abnormal chromosome with two centromeres.
  • • C banding : stains heterochromatin which are regions of the chromosomes at or near centromere. So, C banding will be most useful for dicentric chromosomes.
  • • C banding
  • • So, C banding will be most useful for dicentric chromosomes.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. G-banding: G-banding is the most common banding technique and uses Giemsa stain to stain AT-rich regions. It was developed as an alternative to Q-banding due to the cumbersome nature of Q-banding.
  • • Option A. G-banding:
  • • Option B. NOR-banding: NOR-banding (Nucleolar Organizer Region) is used to stain regions associated with nucleolus formation and is not specifically useful for dicentric chromosomes.
  • • Option B. NOR-banding:
  • • Option D. R-banding: R-banding provides a reverse pattern to G-banding, staining GC-rich regions instead of AT-rich regions. It is not specifically useful for identifying dicentric chromosomes.
  • • Option D. R-banding:
  • • Note – Q banding : uses quinacrine dye (first used dye) and stains repetitive AT rich regions.
  • • Note – Q banding

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ C-banding is the preferred technique for identifying dicentric chromosomes as it specifically stains heterochromatin regions at or near the centromere.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Robbins 10th Ed. / page- 262-263, 293

questions.text: SARS-Cov-2 can be detected by all except? ( INICET NOVEMBER 2022)

options.label: B
options.text: Real-time PCR to detect viral mRNA

options.label: C
options.text: Rapid antigen test to detect spike proteins

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Southern blotting

Explanation:

  • • Real-time PCR (RT-PCR) :
  • • Real-time PCR (RT-PCR)
  • • Method : This technique is used to detect the presence of viral RNA. Nasopharyngeal swabs are typically used as the sample source.
  • • Method : This technique is used to detect the presence of viral RNA. Nasopharyngeal swabs are typically used as the sample source.
  • • Method
  • • Explanation : It is the most sensitive and specific test available for SARS-CoV-2 detection.
  • • Explanation : It is the most sensitive and specific test available for SARS-CoV-2 detection.
  • • Explanation
  • • Rapid Antigen Test :
  • • Rapid Antigen Test
  • • Method : This test detects specific proteins, such as the spike protein, from the virus present in nasopharyngeal secretions.
  • • Method : This test detects specific proteins, such as the spike protein, from the virus present in nasopharyngeal secretions.
  • • Method
  • • Explanation : It provides quicker results compared to PCR but is generally less sensitive.
  • • Explanation : It provides quicker results compared to PCR but is generally less sensitive.
  • • Explanation
  • • ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay) :
  • • ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay)
  • • Method : This technique detects antibodies against spike proteins or the spike proteins themselves.
  • • Method : This technique detects antibodies against spike proteins or the spike proteins themselves.
  • • Method
  • • Explanation : It is used for both diagnostic and serological purposes.
  • • Explanation : It is used for both diagnostic and serological purposes.
  • • Explanation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Southern blotting is not a suitable method for detecting SARS-CoV-2 as it is designed to detect DNA, while SARS-CoV-2 is an RNA virus and requires RNA-specific detection techniques.

questions.text: Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities is seen in methanol intoxication? (INICET NOV 2022)

Ans. B) Metabolic acidosis with high anion gap

questions.text: A patient arrives at the emergency department presenting with symptoms of abdominal pain, vomiting, tachypnea, and tachycardia. Laboratory results are as follows: pH: 7.34, Sodium: 135 mmol/L, Potassium: 5 mmol/L, Bicarbonate: 12 mmol/L, Chloride: 92 mmol/L, RBS: 450 mg/dL. Given these laboratory findings, which of the following statements best describes the patient's acid-base status? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.correct_answer: B. High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ High anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) is characterized by an anion gap greater than 12 mmol/L, indicating an accumulation of unmeasured anions. This condition is often seen in diabetic ketoacidosis, which presents with elevated blood glucose levels and metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions are more susceptible to infections caused by catalase-positive organisms: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chronic granulomatous disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) is an immunodeficiency disorder that makes patients particularly susceptible to infections by catalase-positive organisms due to a defect in the NADPH oxidase enzyme in phagocytes.

questions.text: Total plasma exchange is done in thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura. How does TPE help in the management of TTP? (INICET MAY 2023)

options.label: A

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: D. TPE removes anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies and thereby increases ADAMTS protease activity
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) TPE removes anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies and thereby increases ADAMTS protease activity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ TPE in TTP primarily removes anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies, increasing ADAMTS13 activity and reducing microthrombi formation.

questions.text: A newborn presents with umbilical cord stump bleeding and a history of recurrent bleeding episodes. Laboratory results reveal normal PT, APTT, and platelet count, but a positive clot solubility test. What coagulation factor deficiency is most likely responsible for these symptoms? ( INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Factor XIII

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Factor XIII deficiency presents with umbilical cord bleeding and shows normal PT, aPTT, and platelet count but positive clot solubility test due to unstable clot formation.

questions.text: Which of the following modalities are used for the diagnosis of placenta accreta? (INICET MAY 2021) Ultrasonography MRI Angiography X-ray
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1 and 2 only

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Ultrasonography and MRI are key modalities used in the diagnosis of placenta accreta.
  • • Ultrasonography (1) : This is often the first imaging modality used to diagnose placenta accreta. It helps in visualizing the placental attachment and identifying abnormalities in placental implantation. Color Doppler ultrasonography is particularly useful to assess the blood flow and the vascularity of the placenta, which can indicate abnormal adherence. MRI (2) : MRI is used as a complementary imaging tool when ultrasonography results are inconclusive or to provide a more detailed view. It helps in evaluating the depth of placental invasion into the myometrium and can differentiate between placenta accreta, increta, and percreta. Angiography (3) : While angiography can provide information about blood vessels and may be used in some cases to evaluate blood flow abnormalities, it is not typically a primary diagnostic tool for placenta accreta. It may be used in specific scenarios or to plan surgical management, but it is not generally used for initial diagnosis. X-ray (4) : X-rays are not used in the diagnosis of placenta accreta due to their lack of sensitivity for soft tissue detail and the potential risk to the fetus. X-rays are not helpful in visualizing the placenta or its adherence to the uterine wall.
  • • Ultrasonography (1) : This is often the first imaging modality used to diagnose placenta accreta. It helps in visualizing the placental attachment and identifying abnormalities in placental implantation. Color Doppler ultrasonography is particularly useful to assess the blood flow and the vascularity of the placenta, which can indicate abnormal adherence.
  • • Ultrasonography (1)
  • • MRI (2) : MRI is used as a complementary imaging tool when ultrasonography results are inconclusive or to provide a more detailed view. It helps in evaluating the depth of placental invasion into the myometrium and can differentiate between placenta accreta, increta, and percreta.
  • • MRI (2)
  • • Angiography (3) : While angiography can provide information about blood vessels and may be used in some cases to evaluate blood flow abnormalities, it is not typically a primary diagnostic tool for placenta accreta. It may be used in specific scenarios or to plan surgical management, but it is not generally used for initial diagnosis.
  • • Angiography (3)
  • • X-ray (4) : X-rays are not used in the diagnosis of placenta accreta due to their lack of sensitivity for soft tissue detail and the potential risk to the fetus. X-rays are not helpful in visualizing the placenta or its adherence to the uterine wall.
  • • X-ray (4)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A : Incorrect because it includes Angiography, which is not commonly used for the initial diagnosis of placenta accreta.
  • • Option A
  • • Option C : Incorrect because it includes Angiography, which is not a primary diagnostic tool for placenta accreta, and it excludes Ultrasonography, which is crucial for diagnosis.
  • • Option C
  • • Option D : Incorrect because X-ray is not used for diagnosing placenta accreta and does not contribute to the diagnosis.
  • • Option D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ultrasonography and MRI are the primary modalities used for diagnosing placenta accreta.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1982, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1982, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: Identify the type of marked chromosome in the given karyotype? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Acrocentric

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The marked chromosome is chromosome 13 and the type is acrocentric.
  • • Each chromatid has a long arm “q” and a short arm “p” which are separated by a centromere.
  • • Each chromatid has a long arm “q” and a short arm “p”
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option B. Metacentric: Metacentric chromosomes have the centromere located in the center, creating arms of equal length. Examples include chromosomes 1 and 3.
  • • Option B. Metacentric:
  • • Option C. Submetacentric: Submetacentric chromosomes have the centromere slightly off-center, creating one long arm and one short arm. Most human autosomes and the X chromosome are submetacentric.
  • • Option C. Submetacentric:
  • • Option D. Telocentric: Telocentric chromosomes have the centromere at the very end of the chromosome, creating only one arm. This type is not present in humans.
  • • Option D. Telocentric:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Chromosomes are classified based on the position of the centromere as follows:
  • ➤ Chromosomes are classified based on the position of the centromere as follows:

questions.text: Which of the following isn't considered a benefit of USG compared to Mammography? (INICET MAY 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Can be used for screening mammographically undetectable or clinically non palpable breast mass

options.label: B
options.text: Useful in young females with dense breast

options.label: C
options.text: Differentiates between solid and Cystic lesions in the Breast

questions.correct_answer: A. Can be used for screening mammographically undetectable or clinically non palpable breast mass
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Can be used for screening mammographically undetectable clinically non palpable breast mass

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ultrasound should not be considered a standalone screening tool for non-palpable breast masses or those not detected by mammography. However, it is invaluable in specific scenarios such as evaluating women with dense breasts, distinguishing between cystic and solid breast lesions, and facilitating guided biopsies.

questions.text: What is the frequency of tetanic stimulation used in neuromuscular monitoring? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. 50 Hz

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is the frequency typically used for tetanic stimulation in neuromuscular monitoring. A stimulation of 50 Hz for 5 seconds results in a tetanic contraction. If the patient is under profound neuromuscular blockade, no contraction will be observed. If there's some recovery from blockade, a contraction will be noted but may be weaker than in a patient with no blockade. Fade during or after tetanic stimulation can indicate incomplete recovery from blockade.
  • • Tetanic stimulation is a method used in neuromuscular monitoring to assess the degree of neuromuscular blockade in patients who have received neuromuscular blocking agents (often used during surgeries to produce muscle paralysis). Tetanic stimulation involves giving a high-frequency series of electrical impulses to a peripheral nerve to cause sustained muscle contraction. The response to tetanic stimulation can help determine the depth of neuromuscular blockade and the presence of fade.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 0.2 Hz : This frequency is more representative of a "single twitch" stimulation, where one stimulus is delivered every 5 seconds. It is used to monitor the initial onset and the later stages of recovery from neuromuscular blockade.
  • • Option A. 0.2 Hz
  • • Option B. 2 Hz : This refers to a train-of-four (TOF) stimulation where four stimuli are given at a frequency of 2 Hz (2 stimuli per second). It's a common method of monitoring neuromuscular blockade, especially when assessing for residual blockade. A fading response in the TOF is indicative of neuromuscular blockade.
  • • Option B. 2 Hz
  • • Option C. 20 Hz : This isn't a standard frequency for neuromuscular monitoring.
  • • Option C. 20 Hz

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The frequency of tetanic stimulation used in neuromuscular monitoring is typically 50 Hz.
  • ➤ PATTERN OF NERVE STIMULATION:
  • ➤ PATTERN OF NERVE STIMULATION:
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pg 1359
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pg 1359

questions.text: Which of the following arteries passes in close proximity to the area marked by the arrow in the given image?

options.label: A
options.text: Anterior division of middle cerebral artery

options.label: B
options.text: Anterior division of the middle meningeal artery

options.label: C
options.text: Posterior division of middle cerebral artery

questions.correct_answer: B. Anterior division of the middle meningeal artery
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Anterior division of the middle meningeal artery

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The area marked by an arrow in the given image is pterion and the artery that passes in close proximity to this area is the middle meningeal artery.
  • • The middle meningeal artery, a branch of the maxillary artery, enters the cranium through the foramen spinosum. Once inside, it divides into anterior and posterior branches. The anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery ascends vertically to supply the dura and the calvaria. Importantly, this artery courses in close proximity to the pterion. A blow to the pterion can fracture the thin bone here and rupture this artery, leading to an epidural hematoma.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • option A . Anterior division of middle cerebral artery : This artery is a branch of the internal carotid artery and supplies parts of the frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes of the brain. After the middle cerebral artery (MCA) exits the lateral sulcus, it bifurcates into its anterior and posterior divisions. However, the MCA and its divisions run deep within the brain, within the depths of the lateral sulcus and over the insular cortex. While they are critical for brain function, they don't have a direct relationship to the pterion on the external surface of the skull.
  • • option A
  • • Anterior division of middle cerebral artery
  • • Option C . Posterior division of middle cerebral artery : Similar to the anterior division, the posterior division of the middle cerebral artery runs deep within the brain and does not have a direct relationship to the pterion.
  • • Option C
  • • Posterior division of middle cerebral artery
  • • Option D. Stem of middle meningeal artery: The stem of the middle meningeal artery is the segment between its origin (from the maxillary artery) and its bifurcation into anterior and posterior divisions. As it enters the cranium through the foramen spinosum, the stem is somewhat close to the pterion but it's the anterior division that actually courses near the pterion on the inner surface of the skull.
  • • Option D. Stem of middle meningeal artery:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The pterion is an H shaped sutural junction between four bones of the skull:
  • ➤ The pterion is an H shaped sutural junction between four bones of the skull:
  • ➤ Frontal bone Squamous part of the temporal bone Greater wing of the sphenoid bone Parietal bone
  • ➤ Frontal bone
  • ➤ Squamous part of the temporal bone
  • ➤ Greater wing of the sphenoid bone
  • ➤ Parietal bone

questions.text: A baby is brought to OPD for 10-week DPT vaccination appointment. He previously experienced a fever exceeding 40°C and had an inconsolable cry at 6 weeks old after receiving a vaccination. What would be the recommended course of action moving forward? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Give DT vaccine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Severe reactions (such as high fever >40.5°C, persistent inconsolable crying >3 hours, or hypotonic-hyporesponsive episodes) after a previous DPT dose are indications to withhold the pertussis component in future doses. The child should receive the DT vaccine instead.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vulval cancer

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given image shows a 4 cm × 5 cm irregular fungating lesion present on the left labium majus of the vulva. The most likely diagnosis is vulvar carcinoma. Vulvar cancer is typically characterized by irregular, fungating, or ulcerative lesions on the vulva. These lesions can be painful and may bleed or discharge.
  • • The given image shows a 4 cm × 5 cm irregular fungating lesion present on the left labium majus of the vulva. The most likely diagnosis is vulvar carcinoma.
  • • Vulvar cancer is typically characterized by irregular, fungating, or ulcerative lesions on the vulva. These lesions can be painful and may bleed or discharge.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Vulval hematoma: Vulval hematomas may occur due to direct trauma or accidental injuries. They present as a localized collection of blood within the vulvar tissues, leading to swelling and bruising, but they do not typically form irregular fungating lesions.
  • • Option A. Vulval hematoma:
  • • Option B. Condyloma acuminata: Condyloma acuminata, also known as genital warts, are commonly caused by HPV types 6 and 11.
  • • Option B. Condyloma acuminata:
  • • They appear as multiple, small, cauliflower-like growths and are not typically large, irregular, or fungating.
  • • Option D. Bartholin cyst: A Bartholin cyst occurs when the duct of the Bartholin gland gets blocked due to infection, resulting in a buildup of glandular secretions.
  • • Option D. Bartholin cyst:
  • • It presents as a swelling on one side of the vaginal opening, but it is typically smooth and round, not irregular and fungating.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vulvar cancer often presents as an irregular, fungating lesion on the vulva.
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition pg 337,338
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition pg 337,338

questions.text: Arrange the following in sequence? (INICET NOV 2022) Crowning Engagement Restitution External rotation
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) B, A, C, D

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The sequence of cardinal movements in the mechanism of labor is a series of positions and motions that the fetus goes through as it navigates through the birth canal. These movements are:
  • • Engagement : This is when the fetal head enters the pelvic inlet and the widest part of the head has passed through the pelvic brim. Descent : The downward movement of the fetal head within the pelvic inlet. Flexion : The fetal head bends so the chin is brought closer to the chest, presenting the smallest diameter to the birth canal. Internal Rotation : The fetal head rotates to align with the maternal pelvis. Extension : The fetal head extends as it passes under the symphysis pubis, followed by the crowning (the fetal head remains visible at the vulva without slipping back). Crowning : The fetal head is visible at the vulva without slipping back. Restitution : The fetal head rotates to the position it was in when it engaged in the pelvis. External Rotation : The fetal shoulders rotate to align with the head. Expulsion of the rest of the body : The remainder of the fetal body is delivered.
  • • Engagement : This is when the fetal head enters the pelvic inlet and the widest part of the head has passed through the pelvic brim.
  • • Engagement
  • • Descent : The downward movement of the fetal head within the pelvic inlet.
  • • Descent
  • • Flexion : The fetal head bends so the chin is brought closer to the chest, presenting the smallest diameter to the birth canal.
  • • Flexion
  • • Internal Rotation : The fetal head rotates to align with the maternal pelvis.
  • • Internal Rotation
  • • Extension : The fetal head extends as it passes under the symphysis pubis, followed by the crowning (the fetal head remains visible at the vulva without slipping back).
  • • Extension
  • • Crowning : The fetal head is visible at the vulva without slipping back.
  • • Crowning
  • • Restitution : The fetal head rotates to the position it was in when it engaged in the pelvis.
  • • Restitution
  • • External Rotation : The fetal shoulders rotate to align with the head.
  • • External Rotation
  • • Expulsion of the rest of the body : The remainder of the fetal body is delivered.
  • • Expulsion of the rest of the body
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option B. B, A, D, C : This sequence incorrectly places external rotation before restitution.
  • • Option B. B, A, D, C
  • • Option C. B, C, A, D : This sequence incorrectly places restitution before crowning.
  • • Option C. B, C, A, D
  • • Option D. B, D, A, C : This sequence incorrectly places external rotation before crowning and restitution.
  • • Option D. B, D, A, C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cardinal movements in the mechanism of labor occur in the following sequence: engagement, descent, flexion, internal rotation, extension (preceded by crowning), restitution, external rotation, and expulsion of the rest of the body.
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition pg 145
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition pg 145

questions.text: A young male weighing 46 kg was treated with a drug. It has a Vd of 6 L/kg and clearance of 4.6 L/hour. What is the approximate half-life of this drug? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 40 hours

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The half-life can be calculated using the formula:
  • • t1/2 = 0.693 × Vd/Clearance
  • • Vd given is 6 L/kg, so total Vd = 6 × 46 = 276 L Clearance = 4.6 L/hour Therefore: t1/2 = 0.693 × 276/4.6 ≈ 0.693 × 60 ≈ 40 hours
  • • Vd given is 6 L/kg, so total Vd = 6 × 46 = 276 L
  • • Clearance = 4.6 L/hour Therefore: t1/2 = 0.693 × 276/4.6 ≈ 0.693 × 60 ≈ 40 hours

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The formula for calculating half-life (t1/2 = 0.693 × Vd/Clearance) and remember to account for total Vd when given in L/kg by multiplying with body weight.

questions.text: A patient who used to workout regularly at the gym, gradually developed pain in the hip which is aggravated while squatting. He gives history of regular steroid and creatine use over last six months. There is flattening of femoral head and subchondral cysts were seen on X-ray. What is the likely diagnosis?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) AVN of hip

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Regular steroid is the major risk factor for development of avascular necrosis of the hip. Flattening of femoral head on radiograph is also seen in the avascular necrosis of hip.
  • ➤ Regular steroid is the major risk factor for development of avascular necrosis of the hip.
  • ➤ Flattening of femoral head on radiograph is also seen in the avascular necrosis of hip.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about a patient with G6PD deficiency? (INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: B
options.text: Males and females can be affected

options.label: D
options.text: Reduced oxidative stress inside the red cells

questions.correct_answer: D. Reduced oxidative stress inside the red cells
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ G6PD deficiency increases oxidative stress in red blood cells, leading to hemolysis and formation of Heinz bodies. It affects both males and females, though more commonly males.

questions.text: What causes decrease in GFR? (INICET NOV 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure

questions.correct_answer: C. Decrease in glomerular filtration coefficient
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Decrease in glomerular filtration coefficient

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glomerular filtration coefficient (Kf) and GFR are directly proportional, meaning a decrease in Kf causes a decrease in GFR.

questions.text: 2,3 BPG causes unloading of oxygen to tissues because:

options.label: A
options.text: It decreases ATP production and hence breaks the links between globin chains

options.label: C
options.text: Binds to the central cavity of hemoglobin surrounded by histidine and lysine and favours salt bridge formation

questions.correct_answer: C. Binds to the central cavity of hemoglobin surrounded by histidine and lysine and favours salt bridge formation
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Binds to the central cavity of hemoglobin surrounded by histidine and lysine and favors salt bridge formation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ 2,3 BPG is formed in RL shunt which has no net ATP production 2,3 BPG has negative charge whereas beta chain of hemoglobin has large negative charges due to amino acids His and Lys. Together they form the salt bridges (see fig) which promote formation of taut conformation and helps in deoxygenation.
  • ➤ 2,3 BPG is formed in RL shunt which has no net ATP production
  • ➤ 2,3 BPG has negative charge whereas beta chain of hemoglobin has large negative charges due to amino acids His and Lys. Together they form the salt bridges (see fig) which promote formation of taut conformation and helps in deoxygenation.
  • ➤ When 2,3 BPG levels gets decreased, it promotes relaxed confirmation of Hb resulting in oxygen loading.
  • ➤ When 2,3 BPG levels gets decreased, it promotes relaxed confirmation of Hb resulting in oxygen loading.

questions.text: Open cardiac massage is what kind of wound? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Contaminated

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Open cardiac massage is categorized as a Contaminated wound due to the nature of emergency procedures that may involve rapid and less controlled entry into the chest cavity, leading to a higher risk of infection compared to clean surgeries. This classification underscores the importance of using appropriate antibiotic prophylaxis and stringent postoperative care to manage and minimize the risk of infection
  • ➤ Contaminated

questions.text: The second phase of saliva secretion involves: (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Active Na+ reabsorption, passive CI- reabsorption, passive K+ secretion, active secretion of HCO3-

options.label: B
options.text: Passive Na+ reabsorption, active CI- reabsorption, passive K+ secretion, active secretion of HCO3-

options.label: C
options.text: Passive Na+ secretion, active CI- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-

options.label: D
options.text: Active Na+ reabsorption, passive CI- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-

questions.correct_answer: D. Active Na+ reabsorption, passive CI- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Active Na+ reabsorption, passive CI- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The second phase of saliva secretion involves active Na+ reabsorption, passive Cl- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, and passive secretion of HCO3-, crucial for maintaining electrolyte balance and pH in saliva.

questions.text: Salter Harris Type 1 injury passes through which zone? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hypertrophic zone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypertrophic zone of the physis has a high bone turnover. It is the area where all Salter-Harris injuries occur. Thus, the Type I injuries occurs in the hypertrophic zone of the physis.
  • ➤ Hypertrophic zone of the physis has a high bone turnover.
  • ➤ It is the area where all Salter-Harris injuries occur.
  • ➤ Thus, the Type I injuries occurs in the hypertrophic zone of the physis.

questions.text: All of the following structures are cut in mediolateral episiotomy except? (INICET NOV 2020)

options.label: D
options.text: Transverse perineal branches of pudendal nerves

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Obturator muscle

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The obturator muscle is not cut in a mediolateral episiotomy. It is located deeper in the pelvis and is not involved in the incision made during this procedure.
  • • Structures cut in a mediolateral episiotomy:
  • • Structures cut in a mediolateral episiotomy:
  • • Posterior vaginal wall mucosa Perineal muscles: Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles Bulbospongiosus Part of levator ani Subcutaneous tissue and skin
  • • Posterior vaginal wall mucosa
  • • Posterior vaginal wall mucosa
  • • Perineal muscles: Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles Bulbospongiosus Part of levator ani
  • • Perineal muscles:
  • • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles Bulbospongiosus Part of levator ani
  • • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles
  • • Bulbospongiosus
  • • Part of levator ani
  • • Subcutaneous tissue and skin
  • • Subcutaneous tissue and skin
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • In a mediolateral episiotomy, the following structures are typically cut to facilitate childbirth:
  • • Option A. Transverse perineal muscles: These include the superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles.
  • • Option A. Transverse perineal muscles:
  • • Option C. Bulbospongiosus: A muscle of the perineum that is also incised during the procedure.
  • • Option C. Bulbospongiosus:
  • • Option D. Transverse perineal branches of pudendal nerves: These branches can be affected during the episiotomy.
  • • Option D. Transverse perineal branches of pudendal nerves:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a mediolateral episiotomy, various perineal structures, including the posterior vaginal wall mucosa, superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus, part of the levator ani, subcutaneous tissue, and skin, are incised. The obturator muscle is not involved in this procedure.
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition Pg 649
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition Pg 649

questions.text: The blood investigation of a patient is given below. What is the probable diagnosis? ( INICET Nov 2023) HBsAg - NR, Anti HBs - NR, Anti HBc IgM - NR, Anti HBc total - positive, HBeAg - NR, Anti HBe – NR (NR – Non reactive)

options.label: A
options.text: Acute HBV infection in window period

options.label: C
options.text: HBV infection in the remote past, completely recovered

questions.correct_answer: C. HBV infection in the remote past, completely recovered
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) HBV infection in the remote past, completely recovered

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient's serological markers indicate the following:
  • • HBsAg - Non-Reactive (NR): This suggests that the patient is not currently infected with Hepatitis B.
  • • HBsAg - Non-Reactive (NR): This suggests that the patient is not currently infected with Hepatitis B.
  • • Anti HBs - NR: Lack of antibodies against the Hepatitis B surface antigen suggests no current immunity from vaccination or recent infection.
  • • Anti HBs - NR: Lack of antibodies against the Hepatitis B surface antigen suggests no current immunity from vaccination or recent infection.
  • • Anti HBc IgM - NR: The absence of IgM antibodies against the core antigen indicates no recent acute infection. Anti HBc total - positive: Presence of total core antibodies (including IgG) indicates past exposure to the virus.
  • • Anti HBc IgM - NR: The absence of IgM antibodies against the core antigen indicates no recent acute infection.
  • • Anti HBc total - positive: Presence of total core antibodies (including IgG) indicates past exposure to the virus.
  • • HBeAg - NR: Absence of the e antigen suggests no active viral replication.
  • • HBeAg - NR: Absence of the e antigen suggests no active viral replication.
  • • Anti HBe - NR: Absence of antibodies against the e antigen suggests no current or recent active infection.
  • • Anti HBe - NR: Absence of antibodies against the e antigen suggests no current or recent active infection.
  • • Given these markers, the most likely scenario is that the patient had a Hepatitis B infection in the past and has completely recovered. The presence of Anti HBc total (which is predominantly IgG) signifies past infection. In cases of remote past infection, anti-HBs antibodies may fall below detectable levels, although the patient still has immunity through memory B cells.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Acute HBV infection in window period: In the window period of acute HBV infection, Anti HBc IgM should be positive, which is not the case here.
  • • Option A. Acute HBV infection in window period:
  • • Option B. Immune with recombinant HBV Vaccine: Patients vaccinated against HBV typically have positive Anti HBs and negative Anti HBc total, as they have not been exposed to the virus.
  • • Option B. Immune with recombinant HBV Vaccine:
  • • Option D. Chronic HBV infection inactive carrier: Chronic HBV infection requires the presence of HBsAg for more than six months. The absence of HBsAg rules out chronic infection.
  • • Option D. Chronic HBV infection inactive carrier:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of Anti HBc total (predominantly IgG) with all other markers negative suggests a past HBV infection that has completely resolved.

questions.text: Intercellular communication in eukaryotes is by? ( NICET Nov 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Exosome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Exosomes are key players in intercellular communication in eukaryotes, mediating the transfer of various biomolecules between cells and influencing diverse biological processes.

questions.text: What sign on day 2 would indicate a need for surgery in a patient who was conservatively managed in the ICU after grade 3 splenic trauma? ( INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pneumoperitoneum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pneumoperitoneum is the most concerning sign in a patient with grade 3 splenic trauma and would indicate a need for surgery, as it suggests a perforation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old farmer reports symptoms of fever, body pain, and a cough. A physical examination reveals a black lesion as depicted in the accompanying image. Laboratory tests confirm the presence of IgM antibodies indicative of Scrub Typhus infection. What treatment approach would be most advisable in this case? ( INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Doxycycline alone

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This black lesion is Eschar and this is the acute case of Scrub Typhus.
  • • Causative organism - Rickettsia tsutsugamushi; Vector - Mite
  • • The preferred approach depends on the severity of the condition and individual patient considerations.
  • • Option A. Doxycycline Alone :
  • • Option A. Doxycycline Alone
  • • Use : This is the first-line treatment for Scrub Typhus. Mechanism : Doxycycline works by inhibiting protein synthesis in bacteria, effectively controlling the infection. Why Prefer : It's highly effective and typically well-tolerated, making it suitable for most cases unless contraindicated.
  • • Use : This is the first-line treatment for Scrub Typhus.
  • • Use
  • • Mechanism : Doxycycline works by inhibiting protein synthesis in bacteria, effectively controlling the infection.
  • • Mechanism
  • • Why Prefer : It's highly effective and typically well-tolerated, making it suitable for most cases unless contraindicated.
  • • Why Prefer
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Doxycycline + Azithromycin : Used when there is co-infection with other pathogens that azithromycin can cover or when doxycycline alone isn't adequately effective.
  • • Option B. Doxycycline + Azithromycin
  • • Option C. Ceftriaxone + Doxycycline : This combination might be used in more severe cases or when the patient has complications that might benefit from a broader antibiotic coverage.
  • • Option C. Ceftriaxone + Doxycycline
  • • Option D. Ceftriaxone Alone : While effective against many types of bacteria, it's not the targeted treatment for Scrub Typhus and generally not recommended unless other options are contraindicated.
  • • Option D. Ceftriaxone Alone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Doxycycline alone is usually sufficient and most advisable for uncomplicated Scrub Typhus. Combination therapies may be considered in specific clinical scenarios where co-infections or severe presentations are evident.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy collapsed while playing football. ECG showed V5, V6 inversion and prominent inverted T-waves. 2D echocardiography showed the septal anterior motion of mitral valve leaflet. Which of the following features will be seen on clinical examination and which of the following are true regarding the management? (INICET NOV 2020) Clinical findings a. Pulsus bisferiens b. Pulsus alternans c. Ejection systolic murmur d. Murmur increases on standing e. Murmur decreases on standing Management 1. Beta-blockers are given 2. Beta-blockers are contraindicated 3. ICD is indicated 4. ICD is contraindicated
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Key Points:
  • ➤ Key Points:
  • ➤ All murmurs decrease on standing except MVP and HCM.
  • ➤ All murmurs decrease on standing except MVP and HCM.
  • ➤ Pulsus bisferiens can be seen in HCM
  • ➤ Pulsus bisferiens can be seen in HCM
  • ➤ HCM is characterized by myocyte disarray & fibrosis causing increase risk of sudden cardiac death & arrhythmias.
  • ➤ HCM is characterized by myocyte disarray & fibrosis causing increase risk of sudden cardiac death & arrhythmias.
  • ➤ Pulsus alternans is seen in LVF
  • ➤ Pulsus alternans is seen in LVF

questions.text: Which of the following signs is not typically seen in allergic rhinitis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Otto veraguth folds

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Otto Veraguth folds are not associated with allergic rhinitis but are more commonly seen in individuals with depression.

questions.text: What would happen to the half-life and plasma concentration of a drug which follows first-order kinetics, if the dose is doubled? ( INICET May 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: Half-life doubles and plasma concentration remains the same

options.label: B
options.text: Half-life remains the same and plasma concentration doubles

options.label: C
options.text: Half-life and plasma concentration remains the same

questions.correct_answer: B. Half-life remains the same and plasma concentration doubles
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Half-life remains the same and plasma concentration doubles

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For drugs following first-order kinetics, The rate of elimination of the drug is directly proportional its plasma concentration. So, when the dose is doubled for a drug following first order kinetics, the plasma concentration is also doubled.

questions.text: A patient presents with tear in the anteroinferior aspect of the glenoid capsule and labrum. Identify the lesion. (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation: Ans. A. Bankart’s lesion
